utterances: And therefore they have to charge (unintelligible)…
And the Bank of China.
…to entice those investors, so that's mathematically.
And that's what's irritates me about economists is they, I mean, I'm a businessman and I see the math, and they don't.
Well, interest rates have been - when people look at the relationship they find that surprisingly there isn't a very big relationship.

And you're right, there should be, and the reason there isn't, I suspect, is that if you go out as an individual and you have been a renter and you decide to borrow money to buy a home you don't drive up interest rates even though there's more money being borrowed than before and the reason is that you're a small part of a very large market, you have some kind of affect which is just very, very, very, very small.
And it's surprising but the U.S.
government is a relatively small borrower, at the current level.
We could live in the world where that changes, obviously, if we could continue to live beyond our means, but right now it's surprising how small the impact on interest rates has been.
But I do want to salute…
Well, I'm not an economist but I totally disagree.
Okay, Rex.
Thanks very much for the call.

As many of you have read in the media, I hired the Flynn intel group in 2016 before the election with a mandate to help me understand where the Turkish-American relationship is and where it's going and what the obstacles are to the relationship.
I do want to salute Rex's interest in economic history.

It's important when we face these current of issues of recession and monitoring fiscal policy that we remember that we've done these things in the past, and it's remarkably difficult to figure out whether there were actually successful or not.

There is a general view that often it's too little too late that the government responds either with federal - with physical monitory policy after we're already in a recession leading to effects such as inflation down the road.

But it's very difficult to assess these and as a result we're sort of in a faith-based economics world where, unfortunately, in the world of macroeconomics it's very difficult to discern and measure what works and what doesn't.
Well it's a transition for the moment for macroeconomics to real estate.
Elizabeth Razzi, real estate columnist for The Washington Post, with us from a studio at the paper's headquarters here in Washington, D.C.
And, Elizabeth Razzi, nice to speak with you again.
Oh, nice to talk with you, Neal.
So, the three-quarters of a point last week, half a point this week.
Do interest rate cuts by the Fed then turn around and affect interest rates on people's mortgages?
On some loans, not on the typical 30-year fixed rate mortgage because those are actually influenced by the bond market.
They track the ten-year bond, which is really how long a 30-year mortgage really lives.
So bond markets, the folks on Wall Street and around the world who are bidding on those bonds will decide those interest rates and if they get spooked about inflation, they could actually go up.
They could actually go up even though the Fed interest rates are going down?
The Fed has very little control or influence over 30-year fixed rate mortgages.
They do have influence, a very direct influence, on some other mortgages that will put a lot of money into people's pockets.
Now, is there any sign that the housing market is on the mend?
Not a lot.
What's - but the thing to remember is this is a particularly slow time of the market every year.
What's really going to be interesting is going to be - to watch what happens this spring starting February, late February and see what kind of pent-up demand there might be.
A lot of people have been sitting on the sidelines for maybe two years, buyers and sellers alike.
And, I'm even getting even more questions from people about is it time to buy?
Is it time to get back in?
What's going to happen?
There's a lot of interest out there, and it will be really interesting to see who comes back more, sellers or buyers?
Let's talk with Harold(ph).
Harold's on the line with us from Jacksonville in Florida.
Hello there.
You may have actually answered my question quite a bit.
I thought I had a question that might have been helpful for other listeners.
I'm happy to say that I'll be closing on a house this Friday and when I initiated the loan process, I, in thinking I'm being wise, I went ahead and agreed at that time to a fixed rate.

And I'm wondering is this, you know, is this anything like the experience - someone buys a car and then they drive past a car lot and find that the car that they just bought was a lot cheaper somewhere else.
What do you think, Elizabeth?
Well, you're saying you're locked in your interest rate already?
Yes, I have.
Well, of course, either you probably will be losing out a little bit but maybe not.
I mean, actually, 30-year fix rate mortgages went up a little bit over the last week.
They're quite low.
What rate did you get?
I lost in 6 percent.
That's not so bad.
You might be able to do better now depending on your overall indebtedness and the amount of down payment and that sort of thing that you, have but that's not really something to lose sleep over.
Harold, first of all…
(Unintelligible) makes me feel better.
And first of all, congratulations, and not-so-bad, I'm sure you were hoping for something a little more rousing than that.
Thanks…
You know, I'm glad to hear that.
That means it makes a lot of people who are waiting, I suppose, feel a little bit better about taking a step.
Yeah.
Harold, thanks very much for the call.
And Russell Roberts, in the 30 seconds we have left with you, housing, how much has that played apart in all this turmoil that we're talking about?
Well, there's some indication that the housing sector's troubles which are also related to banking sector troubles are geographically localized.
The states that have a lot of subprime mortgage lending did struggle more recently, California, Florida and Michigan.
And there's hope that the rest of the economy is healthy and if - we should get things fixed up in housing, which will take their natural course.
Economy will be all right.
Russell Roberts, thanks very much for being with us.
My pleasure.
Russell Roberts, a professor of economics at George Mason University, with us here in studio 3A.
Elizabeth Razzi's going to stay with us to answer more of your questions about how this affects the real estate market.

We're also going to be talking with Robert Shiller, the author of ""Irrational Exuberance,"" the man who seemed to have got it pretty well right, and talk about with him about whether he thinks it's hit the bottom.
Stay with us.
If you'd like to join us, 800-989-8255.
E-mail, talk@npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Thank you, Lynn.
Tomorrow at this time, we'll hit the road and head for Baltimore.
We're broadcasting from Morgan State University about race and economic mobility.
And we'd like to hear your stories.
What's the economic trajectory of your family?
Will you do better than your parents?
Will your children do better than you?
E-mail us, talk@npr.org.
Right now, we're talking about the economy for everybody.
The Federal Reserve cut interest rates by another half point today, a cut that was in line with what Wall Street expected, maybe double what Wall Street expected.
If you're feeling financial anxiety today, you're not alone.
We're taking questions and answers about your economic fears, personal credit, housing, the markets, let us know what's on your mind.
Our guest is Elizabeth Razzi, real estate columnist for The Washington Post.
And of course, if you'd like to ask her what your questions are, 800-989-8255.
E-mail us talk@npr.org and you can check out our blog npr.org/blogofthenation.
Elizabeth, we have a e-mail question from Marcus(ph) in Salt Lake City.
One question I haven't seen raised locally or nationally, he writes, is what happens to those of us who aren't of the owning class in the midst of this housing crisis?
I'm not sure if the trend is there nationwide, but here in Salt Lake City, a lot of rental properties even previously low-rent apartments are being listed as condos to be sold for a quick buck.

My lease is nearly up at my current complex and in my search for a new abode, three of the places I've had my eye on recently underwent this conversion, I'd stay where I am but they will become condos in a few months' time as well.
How do you see this affecting renters in the future?
Well, in most places, that's exactly the opposite of what's happening.
Condos that were - that developers were trying to sell were switched over into rentals, and that was suppressing the rent being charged to tenants to a point.
That's not to say the rents have become real great bargains.
And in your market, if that's what you're seeing, this - you only have to two choices: you continue to rent or you try to buy.

Make the decision about buying though not so much what happens to your rent next year but what your plans of are over the next three to five years because you have to be prepared to hang onto it that long to make sure you don't lose money.
Well, joining us now is Robert Shiller, a professor of economics at Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut.
He is with us from a studio there.
And it's very good of you to join us again on this program.
My pleasure.
And you were the one who wrote about ""Irrational Exuberance"" in the housing market.
You've proved to be right time and again.
So do you think at this point, have we hit bottom?
I don't think so.
The data that we at S&P/Case-Shiller indexes have been accelerating downward.
In the latest data that we announced yesterday, our 10-city index went - over the last year, went down 8.4 percent on the year.
And that's a record, and it's actually been accelerating for a couple of years now - the declines, or the rate of increase has been going down for a couple of years.
So no, I don't see in this - our latest report - any signs that we're hitting bottom.
